Well, I am in the Jackson Coliseum.
This is on the Mississippi State Fairgrounds in downtown Jackson, which is a mini version, if you will, of the Superdome in New Orleans or the Houston Astrodome.
And there are about 1,200, 1,300 refugees I'm told here.
Most of them had come prior to Katrina hitting, and most of them are from New Orleans or the Mississippi Gulf Coast near New Orleans.
And it's an amazing scene.
I mean, you know, compared to what we just heard to what things were like in the Superdome, this is luxurious.
I mean, air conditioning is working.

It must be getting--beginning to dawn on people that this is--you know, people running on adrenaline obviously dealing with an emergency, but this is going to run for weeks and weeks and months and months.
You know, most people you talk to initially say they're thankful that they made it out and they're thankful that they made it here.

The primary concern is those who left people behind, particularly those who left people behind in New Orleans, and they haven't been able to get through to them, and they haven't been able to hear from them.
I talked to one person yesterday whose grandmother was in the Superdome.

And this is an 82-year-old woman with considerable health problems.

It's a Herculean task, though, for some people because they barely got out with the clothes on their backs.
